io.github.pr0methean.betterrandom.util

Class LooperThread

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Thread
      • io.github.pr0methean.betterrandom.util.LooperThread
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Cloneable, Runnable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    RandomSeederThread

    public class LooperThread
extends Thread
implements Serializable, Cloneable

    Thread that loops a given task until interrupted (or until JVM shutdown, if it is a daemon thread), with the iterations being transactional. Because of these constraints, it can be serialized and cloned. Subclasses must override iterate() if instantiated without a target Runnable; the only reason this class is concrete is that temporary instances are needed during deserialization.

    Subclasses should override the readResolveConstructorWrapper() method to ensure they are deserialized as a subclass instance.

    iterate()'s body should be reasonably short, since it will block serialization and cloning that would otherwise catch it in mid-iteration.

    Thread state that WILL be restored includes:

    • Thread.getName()
    • Thread.getPriority()
    • getState() == State#NEW
    • getState() == State#TERMINATED
    • Thread.isInterrupted()
    • Thread.isDaemon()

    Thread state that will be restored ONLY if its values are Serializable includes:

    • Thread.getThreadGroup()
    • getUncaughtExceptionHandler()
    • Thread.getContextClassLoader()

    Thread state that will NEVER be restored includes:

    • Program counter, call stack, and local variables. The seederThread will restart.
    • Suspended status (see Thread.suspend()
    • getState() == State#TIMED_WAITING
    • getState() == State#WAITING
    • getState() == State#BLOCKED
    • Thread.getId()
    • Thread.holdsLock(Object)
    Author:
    Chris Hennick
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • LooperThread

        protected LooperThread()
        Constructs a LooperThread with all properties as defaults. Protected because it does not set a target, and thus should only be used in subclasses that override iterate().

      • LooperThread

        public LooperThread(@Nullable Runnable target)
        Constructs a LooperThread with the given target. target should only be null if called from a subclass that overrides iterate().
        Parameters:
        target - If not null, the target this thread will run in iterate().

      • LooperThread

        public LooperThread(ThreadGroup group,
                    @Nullable Runnable target)
        Constructs a LooperThread that belongs to the given ThreadGroup and has the given target. target should only be null if called from a subclass that overrides iterate().
        Parameters:
        group - The ThreadGroup this thread will belong to.
        target - If not null, the target this thread will run in iterate().

        Parameters:

      • LooperThread

        public LooperThread(ThreadGroup group,
                    @Nullable Runnable target,
                    String name)
        Constructs a LooperThread with the given name and target, belonging to the given ThreadGroup. target should only be null if called from a subclass that overrides iterate().
        Parameters:
        group - The ThreadGroup this thread will belong to.
        target - If not null, the target this thread will run in iterate().
        name - the thread name

      • LooperThread

        public LooperThread(ThreadGroup group,
                    @Nullable Runnable target,
                    String name,
                    long stackSize)
        Constructs a LooperThread with the given name and target, belonging to the given ThreadGroup and having the given preferred stack size. target should only be null if called from a subclass that overrides iterate(). See Thread.Thread(ThreadGroup, Runnable, String, long) for caveats about specifying the stack size.
        Parameters:
        group - The ThreadGroup this thread will belong to.
        target - If not null, the target this thread will run in iterate().
        name - the thread name
        stackSize - the desired stack size for the new thread, or zero to indicate that this parameter is to be ignored.

    • Method Detail

      • readResolve

        protected Object readResolve()
                      throws InvalidObjectException
        Use readResolve rather than readObject, because stack size and thread group can only be restored in Thread constructors.
        Returns:
        A LooperThread that will replace this one during deserialization.
        Throws:
        InvalidObjectException - if this LooperThread's serial form is invalid.

      • readResolveConstructorWrapper

        @RequiresNonNull(value={"group","name"})
protected LooperThread readResolveConstructorWrapper()
                                                                                       throws InvalidObjectException
        Returns:
        A new LooperThread whose group is group, whose target is target, whose name is name, whose stack size is stackSize and that either has its subclass fields copied from this one or overrides readResolve() to populate them.
        Throws:
        InvalidObjectException - if this LooperThread's serial form is invalid.

      • iterate

        protected boolean iterate()
                   throws InterruptedException
        The task that will be iterated until it returns false. Cannot be abstract for serialization reasons, but must be overridden in subclasses if they are instantiated without a target Runnable.
        Returns:
        true if this thread should continue to iterate.
        Throws:
        InterruptedException - if any.
        UnsupportedOperationException - if this method has not been overridden.

      • run

        public final void run()
        Description copied from class: java.lang.Thread
        If this thread was constructed using a separate Runnable run object, then that Runnable object's run method is called; otherwise, this method does nothing and returns.

        Subclasses of Thread should override this method.

        Specified by:
        run in interface Runnable
        Overrides:
        run in class Thread
        See Also:
        Thread.start(), Thread.stop(), Thread.Thread(ThreadGroup, Runnable, String)

      • getUncaughtExceptionHandler

        public @Nullable Thread.UncaughtExceptionHandler getUncaughtExceptionHandler()
        Description copied from class: java.lang.Thread
        Returns the handler invoked when this thread abruptly terminates due to an uncaught exception. If this thread has not had an uncaught exception handler explicitly set then this thread's ThreadGroup object is returned, unless this thread has terminated, in which case null is returned.
        Overrides:
        getUncaughtExceptionHandler in class Thread
        Returns:
        the uncaught exception handler for this thread

      • setUncaughtExceptionHandler

        public void setUncaughtExceptionHandler(Thread.UncaughtExceptionHandler handler)
        Description copied from class: java.lang.Thread
        Set the handler invoked when this thread abruptly terminates due to an uncaught exception.

        A thread can take full control of how it responds to uncaught exceptions by having its uncaught exception handler explicitly set. If no such handler is set then the thread's ThreadGroup object acts as its handler.

        Overrides:
        setUncaughtExceptionHandler in class Thread
        Parameters:
        handler - the object to use as this thread's uncaught exception handler. If null then this thread has no explicit handler.
        See Also:
        Thread.setDefaultUncaughtExceptionHandler(java.lang.Thread.UncaughtExceptionHandler), ThreadGroup.uncaughtException(java.lang.Thread, java.lang.Throwable)

      • getState

        public Thread.State getState()
        Description copied from class: java.lang.Thread
        Returns the state of this thread. This method is designed for use in monitoring of the system state, not for synchronization control.
        Overrides:
        getState in class Thread
        Returns:
        this thread's state.

      • start

        public void start()
        Description copied from class: java.lang.Thread
        Causes this thread to begin execution; the Java Virtual Machine calls the run method of this thread.

        The result is that two threads are running concurrently: the current thread (which returns from the call to the start method) and the other thread (which executes its run method).

        It is never legal to start a thread more than once. In particular, a thread may not be restarted once it has completed execution.

        Overrides:
        start in class Thread
        See Also:
        Thread.run(), Thread.stop()

      • clone

        public LooperThread clone()
        Description copied from class: java.lang.Thread
        Throws CloneNotSupportedException as a Thread can not be meaningfully cloned. Construct a new Thread instead.
        Overrides:
        clone in class Thread
        Returns:
        a clone of this instance.
        See Also:
        Cloneable
